Award.AwardTitle: Pathways Project: KC Empower: Universal Access To After School STEM,

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Kinetic City After School is a project supported by a prior NSF award that has produced over 80 activities in areas typical of after school activities such as computer games/simulations, hands-on activities, active play, and art and writing. This pathways project, KC Empower, will redesign and test five activities of the 80 activities currently developed by Kinetic City using a new approach to increase the representation of children and youth with disabilities in informal science settings. The project will test how universal design principles can be integrated with new technologies, not available when most after school STEM content was created, to address the needs of students with disabilities. The technologies used in the redesign include advanced mobile platforms and applications; search engines that sift through audio, image and video files; gaming input devices that respond to body movements; and information restructuring that allows multiple representations of content. The project will test how universal design guidelines will work with new technologies, in the short-term providing hands-on activities more accessible to students with disabilities, while increasing access for all students. The project is expected to lead to a full scale development project that will update all modules in Kinetic City After School. The target audience is 3rd - 5th grade students.

The hypothesis of the project is that designing for disability can strengthen activities designed to increase science knowledge. Rather than making accommodations for persons with disabilities, it is the environment and design that are disabled, and it is better educational practice to rethink the activity from the point of view of all learners, including those with disabilities. Thus the use of universal design will address how best to present material for all users while influenced by the challenges presented by disabled users.

The project includes the Coalition for Science After School, the Center for Applied Special Technology and the Afterschool Alliance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
KC Empower: Universal Access to After School STEM

Universal Design for Learning (UDL) is a framework to provide learning opportunities for all children, regardless of cognitive/behavioral, sensory or motor disabilities. The “Universal” part of UDL means that all learners are given all the options—there isn’t one “regular” activity, and an another special version of the activity for the blind kids, and another one for the deaf kids, etc.

However, today very few Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) learning activities are designed using UDL principles. The KC Empower project aimed to see if UDL can make STEM activities more accessible and effective and to provide guidance for activity designers interested in using UDL. Project staff, advisors and researchers selected five sample activities, representing five general types of learning resources. We tested the activities with kids with different special needs, got feedback from them and their adult caregivers, and then reviewed what we discovered with our advisory board, consisting of some of the top experts in UDL and education. Based on these tests and recommendations, we made changes to the activities and tested them again with our target populations to see if the changes made them more accessible and effective.

Results

All Systems Are Go is a computer game in which children help an on-screen character retrieve his lost internal organs. It involved using a computer mouse to drag organs across a computer screen, and also required reading text (figure 1). In its original form, it was not usable by blind children or children who can’t read, but we modified the game to allow players to navigate and play using two computer keyboard key, “tab” and “spacebar.” We added audio narration for each item on the screen. We enhanced contrast for colorblind and low vision players. The resulting game (figure 2) can be played by blind children, and children who can’t read. Our research found that the resulting game was more engaging and accessible than the original, for children with and without disabilities.

The second activity, Dunk and Flip, was a two-part hands on demonstration in which children learn that air takes up space and has mass. We discovered that materials for the activities were difficult for some children to manipulate, and weren’t effective at holding their attention (figure 3). We made modifications to make the demos easier to assemble, more eye-catching, replicable and observable in a group setting (figure 4).  These modifications improved the activities, but even then, we found that they—and perhaps hands on activities in general—require skilled facilitation by caregivers.

Where the Weird Things Are was a writing activity in which children examined line drawings of fanciful creatures and considered where such animals might live and how their unusual adaptations help them survive (figure 5). For the revised activity, we re-created the artwork as a book of 3D raised images, with colors and textures, with talking smartpens programmed to read textual information out loud (figure 6). The revised activity is accessible to blind children, and more engaging and effective for children with and without disabilities.
